title: Buffet, ca. 1905
medium: Carved and veneered walnut , marble, wrought iron, stained glass
provenance: 2013, Given to Cooper-Hewitt by owner Harry  C. Sigman
dimensions: H x W x D: 157.5 x 124.5 x 47 cm (5 ft. 2 in. x 49 in. x 18 1/2 in.)
description: Walnut body, carved at several places to represent algae, consisting of two cabinets in the base, an open space under two drawers under a horizontal surface covered with a marble slab, all below an upper small wooden shelf backed by a vertical surface consisting of mottled colored glass representing the sea behind wrought iron in the form of seawood; gilded metal drawer pulls.
justification:
This buffet formed part of the dining room furniture in the pattern 'Les Algues' (Seaweed or algae), ca. 1905 (See Roselyne Bouvier, Majorelle, Paris, 1901,&nbsp;fig. 216&nbsp;depicted on p. 197). Elements of the bedroom furniture in this pattern were shown&nbsp;at the Salon des Industries du Mobilier&nbsp;from&nbsp;1905. Other items in the algae pattern, e.g. office furniture, are depicted in the "Majorelle-Nancy: Decorations d'interieurs" sales catalogue. See also other items in the dining room, office and living room furniture in the algae pattern in Majorelle catalogue, plates 51, 69, 88, and 89. 
The buffet is significant for its use of multi-media in harmonious, completely coherent&nbsp;design aesthetic. The mottled colors of the glass&nbsp;on top represent water, with the wrought iron tendrils of the seaweed on the water,&nbsp;that continues into tendrils&nbsp;created in wood on the drawers.&nbsp; The plasticity of the forms belies the hard materials, including the&nbsp;soft-colored marble,&nbsp;which is&nbsp;placed to be&nbsp;a practical as well as aesthetic&nbsp;element, forming a hot pad for a kettle. &nbsp;

tombstone.epitaph: Buffet, ca. 1905. Carved and veneered walnut , marble, wrought iron, stained glass. Gift of Harry C. Sigman. 2013-21-8-a/d.
